conclusion: Liquid will flow out from points A, B, C, and D, and we need to determine which container, E or F, it will flow into after passing through baffles.
There are four input points: A, B, C, and D, and two output containers: E and F.
There are baffles or obstacles that the liquid has to navigate around.
Consider the path of least resistance and how fluids move around obstacles.
Baffles are structures placed in the fluid path to redirect or control the flow.
E and F are collection points or containers where the liquid can accumulate.
Assume A, B, C, and D are arranged in a line from left to right, and E and F are at the bottom.
Assume baffles are placed between A, B, C, D and E, F, directing the flow.
Stream A hits the green baffle and is deflected to the right.
Stream B and C strike the blue slanted barrier, merge and are deflected to the right together.
Stream D drops straight down without meeting any obstacles.

premise: Stream A hits the green baffle and is deflected to the right.
conclusion: Most liquid from A ends in container F, with some droplets reaching container E.

premise: Stream B and C strike the blue slanted barrier, merge and are deflected to the right together.
conclusion: Liquid from B and C ends in container F.

premise: Stream D drops straight down without meeting any obstacles.
conclusion: Liquid from D ends in container F.

premise: Most liquid from A ends in container F, with some droplets reaching container E. Liquid from B and C ends in container F. Liquid from D ends in container F.
conclusion: Most liquid from A, B, C, and D end in container F, with some droplets from A reaching container E.
